Three Approaches for Personalization with Applications to Federated Learning

Abstract

The standard objective in machine learning is to train a single model for all users. However, in many learning scenarios, such as cloud computing and federated learning, it is possible to learn a personalized model per user. In this work, we present a systematic learning-theoretic study of personalization. We propose and analyze three approaches: user clustering, data interpolation, and model interpolation. For all three approaches, we provide learning-theoretic guarantees and efficient algorithms for which we also demonstrate the performance empirically. All of our algorithms are model-agnostic and work for any hypothesis class.

1 Introduction

A popular application of language models is virtual keyboard applications, where the goal is to predict the next word, given the previous wordsÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2018). For example, given â€œI live in the state ofâ€, ideally, it should guess the state the user intended to type. However, suppose we train a single model on all the user data and deploy it, then the model would predict the same state for all users and would not be a good model for most. Similarly, in many practical applications, the distribution of data across clients is highly non-i.i.d.Â and training a single global model for all clients may not be optimal.

Thus, we study the problem of learning personalized models, where the goal is to train a model for each client, based on the clientâ€™s own dataset and the datasets of other clients. Such an approach would be useful in applications with the natural infrastructure to deploy a personalized model for each client, which is the case with large-scale learning scenarios such as federated learning (FL)Â (McMahan etÂ al., 2017).

Before we proceed further, we highlight one of our use cases in FL. In FL, typically a centralized global model is trained based on data from a large number of clients, which may be mobile phones, other mobile devices, or sensors (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016b, a; McMahan etÂ al., 2017; Yang etÂ al., 2019) using a variant of stochastic gradient descent called FedAvg. This global model benefits from having access to client data and can often perform better on several learning problems, including next word prediction (Hard etÂ al., 2018; Yang etÂ al., 2018) and predictive models in health (Brisimi etÂ al., 2018). We refer to AppendixÂ A.1 for more details on FL.

Personalization of machine learning models has been studied extensively for specific applications such as speech recognitionÂ (Yu and Li, 2017). However, many algorithms are speech specific or not suitable for FL due to distributed constraints. Personalization is also related to Hierarchical Bayesian modelsÂ (Gelman, 2006; Allenby etÂ al., 2005). However, they are not directly applicable for FL. Personalization in the context of FL has been studied by several works via multi-task learning (Smith etÂ al., 2017), meta-learningÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019; Khodak etÂ al., 2019), use of local parametersÂ (Arivazhagan etÂ al., 2019; Liang etÂ al., 2020), mixture of expertsÂ (Peterson etÂ al., 2019), finetuning and variantsÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2019; Yu etÂ al., 2020) among others. We refer readers to AppendixÂ A.2 for an overview of works on personalization in FL.

We provide a learning-theoretic framework, generalization guarantees, and computationally efficient algorithms for personalization. Since FL is one of the main frameworks where personalized models can be used, we propose efficient algorithms that take into account computation and communication bottlenecks.

2 Preliminaries

Before describing the mathematical details of personalization, we highlight two related models. The first one is the global model trained on data from all the clients. This can be trained using either standard empirical risk minimizationÂ (Vapnik, 1992) or other methods such as agnostic risk minimization (Mohri etÂ al., 2019). The second baseline model is the purely local model trained only on the clientâ€™s data.

The global model is trained on large amounts of data and generalizes well on unseen test data; however it does not perform well for clients whose data distributions are very different from the global train data distribution. On the other hand, the train data distributions of local models match the ones at inference time, but they do not generalize well due to the scarcity of data.

Personalized models can be viewed as intermediate models between pure-local and global models. Thus, the hope is that they incorporate the generalization properties of the global model and the distribution matching property of the local model. Before we proceed further, we first introduce the notation used in the rest of the paper.

2.2 Local model

We first ask when it is beneficial for a client to participate in global model training. Consider a canonical user with distribution ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1}. Suppose we train a purely local model based on the clientâ€™s data and obtain a model hğ’Ÿ^1subscriptâ„subscript^ğ’Ÿ1h_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{1}}. By standard learning-theoretic toolsÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2018), the performance of this model can be bounded as follows: with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta, the minimizer of empirical risk â„’ğ’Ÿ^1â€‹(h)subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿ1â„{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{1}}(h) satisfies

â„’ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(hğ’Ÿ^1)âˆ’â„’ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(hğ’Ÿ1)=ğ’ªâ€‹(â„œğ’Ÿ1,m1â€‹(â„‹))=ğ’ªâ€‹(d+logâ¡1/Î´m1),subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptâ„subscript^ğ’Ÿ1subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptâ„subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ’ªsubscriptâ„œsubscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ‘š1â„‹ğ’ªğ‘‘1ğ›¿subscriptğ‘š1{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}}(h_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{1}})-{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}}(h_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}})=\mathcal{O}\left({\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1},m_{1}}({\mathscr{H}})\right)=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{d+\log{1}/{\delta}}}{\sqrt{m_{1}}}\right), (1)

where â„œğ’Ÿ1,m1â€‹(â„‹)subscriptâ„œsubscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ‘š1â„‹{\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1},m_{1}}({\mathscr{H}}) is the Rademacher complexity and dğ‘‘d is the pseudo-dimension of the hypothesis class â„‹â„‹{\mathscr{H}}Â (Mohri etÂ al., 2018). Note that pseudo-dimension coincides with VC dimension for 0âˆ’1010-1 loss. FromÂ (1), it is clear that local models perform well when the number of samples m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} is large. However, this is often not the case. In many realistic settings, such as virtual keyboard models, the average number of samples per user is in the order of hundreds, whereas the pseudo-dimension of the hypothesis class is in millionsÂ (Hard etÂ al., 2018). In such cases, the above bound becomes vacuous.

2.3 Uniform global model

The global model is trained by minimizing the empirical risk on the concatenation of all the samples. For Î»âˆˆÎ”pğœ†superscriptÎ”ğ‘\lambda\in\Delta^{p}, the weighted average distribution ğ’ŸÎ»subscriptğ’Ÿğœ†{\mathscr{D}}_{\lambda} is given by âˆ‘kÎ»kâ€‹ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\sum_{k}\lambda_{k}{\mathscr{D}}_{k}. The global model is trained on the concatenated samples from all the users and hence is equivalent to minimize the loss on the distribution ğ’°^=âˆ‘kÎ»kâ€²â€‹ğ’Ÿ^k^ğ’°subscriptğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘˜subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜\hat{{\mathscr{U}}}=\sum_{k}\lambda^{\prime}_{k}\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}, where Î»kâ€²=mk/msubscriptsuperscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘š\lambda^{\prime}_{k}=m_{k}/m. Since the global model is trained on data from all the clients, it may not match the actual underlying client distribution and thus may perform worse.

The divergence between distributions is often measured by a Bregman divergence such as KL-divergence or unnormalized relative entropy. However, such divergences do not consider the underlying machine learning task at hand for example learning the best hypotheses out of â„‹â„‹{\mathscr{H}}. To obtain better bounds, we use the notion of label-discrepancy between distributionsÂ (Mansour etÂ al., 2009b; Mohri and Medina, 2012). For two distributions over features and labels, ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1} and ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2{\mathscr{D}}_{2}, and a class of hypotheses â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}, label-discrepancy(Mohri and Medina, 2012) is given by

discâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2)=maxhâˆˆâ„‹â¡|â„’ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(h)âˆ’â„’ğ’Ÿ2â€‹(h)|.subscriptdiscâ„‹subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2subscriptâ„â„‹subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ1â„subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ2â„\text{disc}_{\mathcal{H}}({\mathscr{D}}_{1},{\mathscr{D}}_{2})=\max_{h\in\mathcal{H}}|{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}}(h)-{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{2}}(h)|.

If the loss of all the hypotheses in the class is the same under both ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1} and ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2{\mathscr{D}}_{2}, then the discrepancy is zero and models trained on ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1} generalize well on ğ’Ÿ2subscriptğ’Ÿ2{\mathscr{D}}_{2} and vice versa.

With the above definitions, it can be shown that the uniform global model generalizes as follows: with probability at least 1âˆ’Î´1ğ›¿1-\delta, the minimizer of empirical risk on the uniform distribution satisfies

â„’ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(hğ’°^)âˆ’â„’ğ’Ÿ1â€‹(hğ’Ÿ1)=ğ’ªâ€‹(â„œğ’°,mâ€‹(â„‹))+discâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’°)=ğ’ªâ€‹(d+logâ¡1/Î´m)+discâ„‹â€‹(ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’°).subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptâ„^ğ’°subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptâ„subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ’ªsubscriptâ„œğ’°ğ‘šâ„‹subscriptdiscâ„‹subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ’°ğ’ªğ‘‘1ğ›¿ğ‘šsubscriptdiscâ„‹subscriptğ’Ÿ1ğ’°{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}}(h_{\hat{\mathscr{U}}})-{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}}(h_{{\mathscr{D}}_{1}})=\mathcal{O}\left({\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathscr{U}},m}({\mathscr{H}})\right)+\text{disc}_{\mathcal{H}}({\mathscr{D}}_{1},{\mathscr{U}})=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\sqrt{d+\log{1}/{\delta}}}{\sqrt{m}}\right)+\text{disc}_{\mathcal{H}}({\mathscr{D}}_{1},{\mathscr{U}}). (2)

Since the global model is trained on the concatenation of all usersâ€™ data, it generalizes well. However, due to the distribution mismatch, the model may not perform well for a specific user. If ğ’°=âˆ‘kÎ»kâ€²â€‹ğ’Ÿkğ’°subscriptğ‘˜subscriptsuperscriptğœ†â€²ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{{\mathscr{U}}}=\sum_{k}\lambda^{\prime}_{k}{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}, the difference between local and global models depends on the discrepancy between ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1} and ğ’°ğ’°{\mathscr{U}}, m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} the number of samples from the domain ğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ1{\mathscr{D}}_{1}, and the total number of samples mğ‘šm. While in most practical applications m1subscriptğ‘š1m_{1} is small and hence a global model usually performs better, this is not guaranteed. We provide a simple example illustrating such a case in AppendixÂ B.1.

Since the uniform global model assigns weight mk/msubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šm_{k}/m to client kğ‘˜k, clients with larger numbers of samples receive higher importance. This can adversely affect clients with small amounts of data. Furthermore, byÂ (2), the model may not generalize well for clients whose distribution is different than the uniform distribution. Thus,Â (1) andÂ (2) give some guidelines under which it is beneficial for clients to participate in global model training.

Instead of using uniform weighting of samples, one can use agnostic risk proposed byÂ Mohri etÂ al. (2019), which is more risk averse. We refer to AppendixÂ B.2 for details about the agnostic risk minimization.

3 Our contributions

We ask if personalization can be achieved by an intermediate model between the local and global models. Furthermore, for ease of applicability and to satisfy the communication constraints in FL, we focus on scalable algorithms with low communication bottleneck. This gives rise to three natural algorithms, which are orthogonal and can be used separately or together.

  • â€¢

    Train a model for subsets of users: we can cluster users into groups and train a model for each group. We refer to this as user clustering, or more refinely hypothesis-based clustering.

  • â€¢

    Train a model on interpolated data: we can combine the local and global data and train a model on their combination. We refer to this as data interpolation.

  • â€¢

    Combine local and global models: we can train a local and a global model and use their combination. We refer to this as model interpolation.

We provide generalization bounds and communication-efficient algorithms for all of the above methods. We show that the above three methods has small communication bottleneck and enjoys qualitative privacy benefits similar to training a global model. Of the three proposed approaches, data interpolation has non-trivial communication cost and data security. We show that data interpolation can be implemented with small communication overhead in SectionÂ 5. We also show discuss data security aspect and methods to improve it in AppendixÂ D.3.

Of the remaining methods, model interpolation has the same communication cost and security as that of training a single model. Clustering has the same data security as that of training single models, but the communication cost is qğ‘q times that of training a single model, where qğ‘q is the number of clusters. In the rest of the paper, we study each of the above methods.

4 User clustering

Instead of training a single global model, a natural approach is to cluster clients into groups and train a model for each group. This is an intermediate model between a purely local and global model and provides a trade-off between generalization and distribution mismatch. If we have a clustering of users, then we can naturally find a model for each user using standard optimization techniques. In this section, we ask how to define clusters. Clustering is a classical problem with a broad literature and known algorithmsÂ (Jain, 2010). We argue that, since the subsequent application of our clustering is known, incorporating it into the clustering algorithm will be beneficial. We refer readers to AppendixÂ C.1 for more details on comparison to baseline works.

4.1 Hypothesis-based clustering

Consider the scenario where we are interested in finding clusters of images for a facial recognition task. Suppose we are interested in finding clusters of users for each gender and find a good model for each cluster. If we naively use the Bregman divergence clustering, it may focus on clustering based on the image background e.g., outdoor or indoors to find clusters instead of gender.

To overcome this, we propose to incorporate the task at hand to obtain better clusters. We refer to this approach as hypothesis-based clustering and show that it admits better generalization bounds than the Bregman divergence approach. We partition users into qğ‘q clusters and find the best hypothesis for each cluster. In particular, we use the following optimization:

minh1,â€¦,hqâ€‹âˆ‘k=1pÎ»kâ‹…miniâˆˆ[q]â¡â„’ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(hi),subscriptsubscriptâ„1â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1â‹…subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–\min_{h_{1},\ldots,h_{q}}\sum^{p}_{k=1}\lambda_{k}\cdot\min_{i\in[q]}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h_{i}), (3)

where Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k} is the importance of client kğ‘˜k. The above loss function trains qğ‘q best hypotheses and naturally divides ğ’³Ã—ğ’´ğ’³ğ’´\mathcal{X}\times\mathcal{Y} into qğ‘q partitions, where each partition is associated with a particular hypothesis hksubscriptâ„ğ‘˜h_{k}. In practice, we only have access to the empirical distributions ğ’Ÿ^ksubscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}. We replace â„’ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(hi)subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h_{i}) by â„’ğ’Ÿ^kâ€‹(hi)subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h_{i}) in optimization. To simplify the analysis, we use the fraction of samples from each user mk/msubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šm_{k}/m as Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k}. An alternative approach is to use Î»k=1/psubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜1ğ‘\lambda_{k}=1/p for all users, which assigns equal weight to all clients. The analysis is similar and we omit it to be concise.

4.2 Generalization bounds

We now analyze the generalization properties of this technique. We bound the maximum difference between true cluster based loss and empirical cluster based loss for all hypotheses. We note that such a generalization bound holds for any clustering algorithm (see AppendixÂ C.2).

Let C1,C2â€‹â€¦,Cqsubscriptğ¶1subscriptğ¶2â€¦subscriptğ¶ğ‘C_{1},C_{2}\ldots,C_{q} be the clusters and let mCisubscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–m_{C_{i}} be the number of samples from cluster iğ‘–i. Let ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–{\mathscr{C}}_{i} and ğ’^isubscript^ğ’ğ‘–\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}}_{i} be the empirical and true distributions of cluster ğ’isubscriptğ’ğ‘–{\mathscr{C}}_{i}. The above learning bound can be understood as follows. For good generalization, the average number of samples per user m/pğ‘šğ‘m/p should be larger than the logarithm of the number of clusters, and the average number of samples per cluster m/qğ‘šğ‘m/q should be larger than the pseudo-dimension of the overall model. Somewhat surprisingly, these results do not depend on the minimum number of samples per clients and instead depend only on the average statistics.

To make a comparison between the local performanceÂ (1) and the global model performanceÂ (2), observe that combiningÂ (8) and CorollaryÂ 4.2 together with the definition of discrepancy yields

âˆ‘k=1pmkmâ‹…(â„’ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(h^fâ€‹(k))âˆ’minhâˆˆHâ¡â„’ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(h))â‰¤2â€‹pâ€‹logâ¡2â€‹qÎ´m+dâ€‹qâ€‹emâ€‹logâ¡md+âˆ‘k=1pmkmâ€‹discâ€‹(ğ’Ÿk,ğ’fâ€‹(k)),subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1â‹…subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscript^â„ğ‘“ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ»subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„2ğ‘2ğ‘ğ›¿ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘šğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šdiscsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptğ’ğ‘“ğ‘˜\displaystyle\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{m_{k}}{m}\cdot\left({\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(\widehat{h}_{f(k)})-\min_{h\in H}{\mathscr{L}}_{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}(h)\right)\leq 2\sqrt{\frac{p\log\frac{2q}{\delta}}{m}}+\sqrt{\frac{dqe}{m}\log\frac{m}{d}}+\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{m_{k}}{m}\text{disc}({\mathscr{D}}_{k},{\mathscr{C}}_{f(k)}),

where f:[p]â†’[q]:ğ‘“â†’delimited-[]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘f\colon[p]\to[q] is the mapping from users to clusters. Thus, the generalization bound is in between that of the local and global model. For q=1ğ‘1q=1, it yields the global model, and for q=pğ‘ğ‘q=p, it yields the local model. As we increase qğ‘q, the generalization decreases and the discrepancy term gets smaller. Allowing a general qğ‘q lets us choose the best clustering scheme and provides a smooth trade-off between the generalization and the distribution matching. In practice, we choose small values of q>1ğ‘1q>1. We further note that we are not restricted to using the same value of qğ‘q for all clients. We can find clusters for several values of qğ‘q and use the best one for each client separately using a hold-out set of samples.

4.3 Algorithm : HypCluster

We provide an expectation-maximization (EM)-type algorithm for finding clusters and hypotheses. A naive EM modification may require heavy computation and communication resources. To overcome this, we propose a stochastic EM algorithm in HypCluster. In the algorithm, we denote clusters via a mapping f:[p]â†’[q]:ğ‘“â†’delimited-[]ğ‘delimited-[]ğ‘f\colon[p]\to[q], where fâ€‹(k)ğ‘“ğ‘˜f(k) denotes the cluster of client kğ‘˜k. Similar to kğ‘˜k-means, HypCluster is not guaranteed to converge to the true optimum, but, as stated in the beginning of the previous section, the generalization guarantee of TheoremÂ 4.1 still holds here.

5 Data interpolation

From the point of view of client kğ‘˜k, there is a small amount of data with distribution ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}} and a large amount of data from the global or clustered distribution ğ’ğ’{{\mathscr{C}}}. How are we to use auxiliary data from ğ’ğ’{\mathscr{C}} to improve the model accuracy on ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\mathscr{D}}_{k}? This relates the problem of personalization to domain adaptation. In domain adaptation, there is a single source distribution, which is the global data or the cluster data, and a single target distribution, which is the local client data. As in domain adaptation with target labelsÂ (Blitzer etÂ al., 2008), we have at our disposal a large amount of labeled data from the source (global data) and a small amount of labeled data from the target (personal data). We propose to minimize the loss on the concatenated data,

Î»â‹…ğ’Ÿk+(1âˆ’Î»)â‹…ğ’,â‹…ğœ†subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â‹…1ğœ†ğ’\lambda\cdot{\mathscr{D}}_{k}+(1-\lambda)\cdot{\mathscr{C}}, (5)

where Î»ğœ†\lambda is a hyper-parameter and can be obtained by either cross validation or by using the generalization bounds ofÂ Blitzer etÂ al. (2008). ğ’ğ’{\mathscr{C}} can either be the uniform distribution ğ’°ğ’°{\mathscr{U}} or one of the distributions obtained via clustering.

Personalization is different from most domain adaptation works as they assume they only have access to unlabeled target dataÂ (Mansour etÂ al., 2009a; Ganin etÂ al., 2016; Zhao etÂ al., 2018a), whereas in personalization we have access to labeled target data. Secondly, we have one target domain per client, which makes our problem computationally expensive, which we discuss next. Given the known learning-theoretic bounds, a natural question is if we can efficiently estimate the best hypothesis for a given Î»ğœ†\lambda. However, note that naive approaches suffer from the following drawbacks. If we optimize for each client separately, the time complexity of learning per client is ğ’ªâ€‹(m)ğ’ªğ‘š\mathcal{O}(m) and the overall time complexity is ğ’ªâ€‹(mâ‹…p)ğ’ªâ‹…ğ‘šğ‘\mathcal{O}(m\cdot p).

In addition to the computation time, the algorithm also admits a high communication cost in FL. This is because, to train the model with a Î»ğœ†\lambda-weighted mixture requires the client to admit access to the entire dataset ğ’^^ğ’\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}}, which incurs communication cost ğ’ªâ€‹(m)ğ’ªğ‘š\mathcal{O}(m). One empirically popular approach to overcome this is the fine-tuning approach, where the central model is fine-tuned on the local dataÂ (Wang etÂ al., 2019). However, to the best of our knowledge, there are no theoretical guarantees and the algorithm may be prone to catastrophic forgettingÂ (Goodfellow etÂ al., 2013). In fine-tuning, the models are typically trained first on the global data and then on the clientâ€™s local data. Hence, the order in which samples are seen are not random. Furthermore, we only care about the modelsâ€™ performance on the local data. Hence, one cannot directly use known online-to-batch conversion results from online learning to obtain theoretical guarantees.

We propose Dapper, a theoretically motivated and efficient algorithm to overcome the above issues. The algorithm first trains a central model on the overall empirical distribution ğ’^^ğ’\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}}. Then for each client, it subsamples ğ’^^ğ’\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}} to create a smaller dataset of size ğ’â€²^^superscriptğ’â€²\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}^{\prime}} of size râ‹…mkâ‹…ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜r\cdot m_{k}, where rğ‘Ÿr is a constant. It then minimizes the loss on weighted combination of two datasets i.e., Î»â€‹â„’ğ’Ÿ^kâ€‹(h)+(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹â„’ğ’â€²^â€‹(h)ğœ†subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„1ğœ†subscriptâ„’^superscriptğ’â€²â„\lambda{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}}(h)+(1-\lambda){\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}^{\prime}}}(h) for several values of Î»ğœ†\lambda. Finally, it chooses the best Î»ğœ†\lambda using cross-validation. The algorithm is efficient both in terms of its communication complexity which is râ‹…mkâ‹…ğ‘Ÿsubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜r\cdot m_{k} and its computation time, which is at most (r+1)â‹…mkâ‹…ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜(r+1)\cdot m_{k}. Hence, the overall communication and computation time is ğ’ªâ€‹(râ‹…m)ğ’ªâ‹…ğ‘Ÿğ‘š\mathcal{O}(r\cdot m). Due to space constraints, we relegate the pseudo-code of the algorithm to AppendixÂ D.2.

We analyze Dapper when the loss function is strongly convex in the hypothesis parameters hâ„h and show that the model minimizes the intended loss to the desired accuracy. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first fine-tuning algorithm with provable guarantees.

To prove convergence guarantees, we need to ask what the desired convergence guarantee is. Usually, models are required to converge to the generalization guarantee and we use the same criterion. To this end, we first state a known generalization theorem. Let hÎ»^=argminÎ»â€‹â„’ğ’Ÿ^kâ€‹(h)+(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹â„’ğ’^â€‹(h)subscriptâ„^ğœ†argminğœ†subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„1ğœ†subscriptâ„’^ğ’â„h_{\widehat{\lambda}}=\operatorname*{argmin}\lambda{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}}(h)+(1-\lambda){\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}}}(h) and hÎ»=argminÎ»â€‹â„’ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(h)+(1âˆ’Î»)â€‹â„’ğ’â€‹(h)subscriptâ„ğœ†argminğœ†subscriptâ„’subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â„1ğœ†subscriptâ„’ğ’â„h_{\lambda}=\operatorname*{argmin}\lambda{\mathscr{L}}_{{{\mathscr{D}}_{k}}}(h)+(1-\lambda){\mathscr{L}}_{{{\mathscr{C}}}}(h).

While the above algorithm reduces the amount of data transfer and is computationally efficient, it may be vulnerable to privacy issues in applications such as FL. We propose several alternatives to overcome these privacy issues in AppendixÂ D.3.

7 Experiments

7.1 Synthetic dataset

We first demonstrate the proposed algorithms on a synthetic dataset for density estimation. Let ğ’³=âˆ…ğ’³{\mathscr{X}}=\emptyset, ğ’´=[d]ğ’´delimited-[]ğ‘‘{\mathscr{Y}}=[d], and d=50ğ‘‘50d=50. Let â„“â„“\ell be cross entropy loss and the number of users p=100ğ‘100p=100. We create client distributions as a mixture of a uniform component, a cluster component, and an individual component.

The details of the distributions are in AppendixÂ F.1. We evaluate the algorithms as we vary the number of samples per user. The results are in FigureÂ 2. HypCluster performs the best when the number of samples per user mksubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜m_{k} is very small. If mksubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜m_{k} is large, Mapper performs the best followed closely by Finetune and Dapper. However, the difference between Finetune and Dapper is statistically insignificant. In order to understand the effect of clustering, we evaluate various clustering algorithms as a function of qğ‘q when mk=100subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜100m_{k}=100, and the results are in TableÂ 1. Since the clients are naturally divided into four clusters, as we increase qğ‘q, the test loss steadily decreases till the number of clusters reaches 444 and then remains constant.

7.2 EMNIST dataset

We evaluate the proposed algorithms on the federated EMNIST-62 datasetÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018) provided by TensorFlow Federated (TFF). The dataset consists of 3400 usersâ€™ examples that are each one of 62 classes. We select 2500 users to train the global models (referred to as seen) and leave the remaining 900 as unseen clients reserved for evaluation only. We shuffle the clients first before splitting as the original client ordering results in disjoint model performance. The reported metrics are uniformly averaged across clients similar to previous worksÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019). For model architecture, we use a two-layer convolutional neural net. We refer to AppendixÂ F.2 for more details on the architecture and training procedure.

The test results for seen and unseen clients are in TableÂ 2 and TableÂ 3, respectively. We trained models with FedAvg, AgnosticÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), and HypCluster and combined them with Finetune, Dapper, and Mapper. We observe that HypCluster with two clusters performs significantly better compared to FedAvg and Agnostic models and improves accuracy by at least 4.3%percent4.34.3\%. Thus clustering is significantly better than training a single global model.

The remaining algorithms Dapper and Mapper improve the accuracy by another 1%percent1~{}1\% compared to HypCluster, but the EMNIST dataset is small and standard deviation in our experiments was in the order of 0.1%percent0.10.1\% and hence their improvement over Finetune is not statistically significant. However, these algorithms have provable generalization guarantees and thus would be more risk averse.

8 Conclusion

We presented a systematic learning-theoretic study of personalization in learning and proposed and analyzed three algorithms: user clustering, data interpolation, and model interpolation. For all three approaches, we provided learning theoretic guarantees and efficient algorithms. Finally, we empirically demonstrated the usefulness of the proposed approaches on synthetic and EMNIST datasets.

Appendix A Related works

A.1 Federated learning

FL was introduced byÂ McMahan etÂ al. (2017) as an efficient method for training models in a distributed way. They proposed a new communication-efficient optimization algorithm called FedAvg. They also showed that the training procedure provides additional privacy benefits. The introduction of FL has given rise to several interesting research problems, including the design of more efficient communication strategies (KoneÄná»³ etÂ al., 2016b, a; Suresh etÂ al., 2017; Stich, 2018; Karimireddy etÂ al., 2019), the study of lower bounds for parallel stochastic optimization with a dependency graph (Woodworth etÂ al., 2018), devising efficient distributed optimization methods benefiting from differential privacy guarantees (Agarwal etÂ al., 2018), stochastic optimization solutions for the agnostic formulation (Mohri etÂ al., 2019), and incorporating cryptographic techniques (Bonawitz etÂ al., 2017), meta-learningÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2018), see (Li etÂ al., 2019; Kairouz etÂ al., 2019) for an in-depth survey of recent work in FL.

Federated learning often results in improved performance, as reported in several learning problems, including next word prediction (Hard etÂ al., 2018; Yang etÂ al., 2018), vocabulary estimation (Chen etÂ al., 2019a), emoji prediction (Ramaswamy etÂ al., 2019), decoder models (Chen etÂ al., 2019b), low latency vehicle-to-vehicle communication (Samarakoon etÂ al., 2018), and predictive models in health (Brisimi etÂ al., 2018).

A.2 Personalization in federated learning

There are several recent works that focus on multi-task and meta-learning in the context of federated learning. Smith etÂ al. (2017) studied the problem of federated multi-task learning and proposed MOCHA, an algorithm that jointly learns parameters and a similarity matrix between user tasks. MOCHA tackles various aspects of distributed multitask learning including communication constraints, stragglers, and fault tolerance. They focus on the convex setting and their application to non-convex deep learning models where strong duality is no longer guaranteed is unclear.

Jiang etÂ al. (2019) drew interesting connections between FedAvg and first-order model agnostic meta-learning (MAML) (Finn etÂ al., 2017) and showed that FedAvg is in fact already a meta-learning algorithm. Fallah etÂ al. (2020) also proposed to use the MAML objective in a global model training to obtain a better personalizable global model. Khodak etÂ al. (2019) proposed ARUBA that improves upon gradient-based meta-learning approaches. A variational approach for multi-task learning was proposed by Corinzia and Buhmann (2019). Recently, Hanzely and RichtÃ¡rik (2020) proposed to learn a model per user by adding an â„“2subscriptâ„“2\ell_{2} penalty on model parameters to ensure they are similar.

Another line of work uses a set of local parameters, which are trained per-client, and a set of global parameters, which are trained using FL. For example, Bui etÂ al. (2019) proposed to use user-representations by having a set of client-specific local parameters, which are trained per-client and a set of global parameters, which are trained using FL. Arivazhagan etÂ al. (2019); Liang etÂ al. (2020) proposed to store some layers of the model locally, while training the rest of the model with federated learning.

Peterson etÂ al. (2019) proposed to use techniques from a mixture of experts literature and their approach is similar to our approach of model interpolation, but they learn an interpolation weight based on features. Furthermore, there are no theoretical guarantees for their approach. A theoretical analysis of interpolation models without variable mixing weights was recently presented in Agarwal etÂ al. (2020). Concurrent to this work, Deng etÂ al. (2020) proposed to use an interpolation of a local and global model. Their approach is similar to model interpolation in our paper.

Wang etÂ al. (2019) showed that federated models can be fine-tuned based on local data. They proposed methods to find the best hyper-parameters for fine-tuning and showed that it improves the next word prediction of language models in virtual keyboard applications. Yu etÂ al. (2020) proposed several variants of the fine-tuning approach, including training only a few layers of the networks, adding a local penalty term in the form of model distillation, or elastic weight averaging to the fine-tuning objective to improve local adaptation.

Zhao etÂ al. (2018b) showed that one can improve the accuracy of FedAvg, by sharing a small amount of public data to reduce the non-i.i.d.Â nature of the client data. Sattler etÂ al. (2019) proposed to use cosine-similarity between gradient updates for clustering in federated learning. However, their approach requires all clients to participate in each round and hence is computationally infeasible. Personalization in other settings such as peer-to-peer networks have been studied by Zantedeschi etÂ al. (2019). We refer the readers to (Kulkarni etÂ al., 2020) for a survey of algorithms for personalization in FL.

Appendix B Global models

Appendix C Supplementary material for clustering

C.1 Baselines

If we have meta-features about the data samples and clients, such as location or type of device, we can use them to find clusters. This can be achieved by algorithms such as kğ‘˜k-means or variants. This approach depends on the knowledge of the meta-features and their relationship to the set of hypotheses under consideration. While it may be reasonable in many circumstances, it may not be always feasible. If there are no meta-features, a natural approach is to cluster using a Bregman divergence defined over the distributions ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\mathscr{D}}_{k}Â (Banerjee etÂ al., 2005). However, it is likely that we would overfit as the generalization of the density estimation depends on the covering number of the class of distributions ğ’Ÿ1,ğ’Ÿ2,â€¦,ğ’Ÿpsubscriptğ’Ÿ1subscriptğ’Ÿ2â€¦subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘{\mathscr{D}}_{1},{\mathscr{D}}_{2},\ldots,{\mathscr{D}}_{p}, which in general can be much larger than that of the class of hypotheses â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}. To overcome this, we propose an approach based on hypotheses under consideration which we discuss next.

C.2 Generalization of clustering algorithms

Recall that we solve for

minh1,â€¦,hqâ€‹âˆ‘k=1pmkmâ‹…miniâˆˆ[q]â¡â„’ğ’Ÿ^kâ€‹(hi).subscriptsubscriptâ„1â€¦subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1â‹…subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘–\min_{h_{1},\ldots,h_{q}}\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{m_{k}}{m}\cdot\min_{i\in[q]}{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}}(h_{i}). (7)
Lemma C.1.

where the last inequality follows from standard learning-theoretic guarantees and the definition of Rademacher complexityÂ (Mohri etÂ al., 2018). The proof follows by combining the above equations, normalizing by mğ‘šm, and the union bound.

C.4 Proof of CorollaryÂ 4.2

We show that for any clustering,

âˆ‘i=1qmCimâ€‹â„œğ’i,mCiâ€‹(â„‹)â‰¤dâ€‹pmâ€‹logâ¡eâ€‹md.subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptâ„œsubscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–â„‹ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘‘\sum^{q}_{i=1}\frac{m_{C_{i}}}{m}{\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathscr{C}}_{i},m_{C_{i}}}({\mathscr{H}})\leq\sqrt{\frac{dp}{m}\log\frac{em}{d}}.

The proof then follows from TheoremÂ 4.1. To prove the above observation, observe that

âˆ‘i=1qmCimâ€‹â„œğ’i,mCiâ€‹(â„‹)subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘šsubscriptâ„œsubscriptğ’ğ‘–subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–â„‹\displaystyle\sum^{q}_{i=1}\frac{m_{C_{i}}}{m}{\mathfrak{R}}_{{\mathscr{C}}_{i},m_{C_{i}}}({\mathscr{H}}) â‰¤âˆ‘i=1qmCimâ€‹dâ€‹pmCiâ€‹logâ¡eâ€‹mCidâ‰¤âˆ‘i=1qmCimâ€‹dâ€‹pmCiâ€‹logâ¡eâ€‹mdabsentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘’subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘‘\displaystyle\leq\sum^{q}_{i=1}\frac{m_{C_{i}}}{m}\sqrt{\frac{dp}{m_{C_{i}}}\log\frac{em_{C_{i}}}{d}}\leq\sum^{q}_{i=1}\frac{m_{C_{i}}}{m}\sqrt{\frac{dp}{m_{C_{i}}}\log\frac{em}{d}}
â‰¤âˆ‘i=1q1mâ€‹âˆ‘i=1qdâ€‹pâ€‹mCiâ€‹logâ¡eâ€‹mdâ‰¤dâ€‹qmâ€‹logâ¡eâ€‹md,absentsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–11ğ‘šsubscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘–1ğ‘‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘šsubscriptğ¶ğ‘–ğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘‘ğ‘‘ğ‘ğ‘šğ‘’ğ‘šğ‘‘\displaystyle\leq\sum^{q}_{i=1}\frac{1}{m}\sum^{q}_{i=1}\sqrt{{dp}{m_{C_{i}}}\log\frac{em}{d}}\leq\sqrt{\frac{dq}{m}\log\frac{em}{d}},

where the last inequality follows from Jensenâ€™s inequality.

D.2 Dapper pseudo-code

We provide pseudo-code for the Dapper algorithm in FigureÂ 3.

D.3 Practical considerations

While the above algorithm reduces the amount of data transfer and is computationally efficient, it may be vulnerable to privacy issues in applications such as FL. To overcome that, we propose several alternatives:

  1. 1.

    Sufficient statistics: in many scenarios, instead of the actual data, we only need some sufficient statistics. For example in regression with â„“22subscriptsuperscriptâ„“22\ell^{2}_{2} loss, we only need the covariance matrix of the dataset from ğ’^^ğ’\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}}.

  2. 2.

    Generative models: for problems such as density estimation and language modelling, we can use the centralized model to generate synthetic samples from hcsubscriptâ„ğ‘h_{c} and use that as an approximation to ğ’â€²^^superscriptğ’â€²\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}^{\prime}}. For other applications, one can train a GAN and send the GAN to the clients and the clients can sample from the GAN to create the dataset ğ’â€²^^superscriptğ’â€²\widehat{{\mathscr{C}}^{\prime}}Â (Augenstein etÂ al., 2019).

  3. 3.

    Proxy public data: if it is not feasible to send the actual user data, one could send proxy public data instead. While this may not be theoretically optimal, it will still avoid overfitting to the local data.

E.2 Mapper algorithms

We first show that this method of independently finding the local models is sub-optimal with an example.

Example E.1.

Consider the following discrete distribution estimation problem. Let â„‹csubscriptâ„‹ğ‘\mathcal{H}_{c} be the set of distributions over dğ‘‘d values and let â„‹lsubscriptâ„‹ğ‘™\mathcal{H}_{l} be the set of distributions with support size 111. For even kğ‘˜k, let ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(1)=ğ’Ÿevenâ€‹(1)=1.0subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜1subscriptğ’Ÿeven11.0{\mathscr{D}}_{k}(1)={\mathscr{D}}_{\text{even}}(1)=1.0 and for odd kğ‘˜k, let ğ’Ÿkâ€‹(y)=ğ’Ÿoddâ€‹(y)=1/dsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜ğ‘¦subscriptğ’Ÿoddğ‘¦1ğ‘‘{\mathscr{D}}_{k}(y)={\mathscr{D}}_{\text{odd}}(y)=1/d for all 1â‰¤yâ‰¤d1ğ‘¦ğ‘‘1\leq y\leq d. Let the number of clients pğ‘p be very large and the number of samples per client a constant, say ten. Suppose we consider the log-loss.

The intuition behind this example is that since we have only one example per domain, we can only derive good estimates for the local model for even kğ‘˜k and we need to estimate the global model jointly from the odd clients. With this approach, the optimal solution is as follows. For even kğ‘˜k, hl,k=ğ’Ÿksubscriptâ„ğ‘™ğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜h_{l,k}={\mathscr{D}}_{k} and Î»k=1.0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜1.0\lambda_{k}=1.0. For odd kğ‘˜k, Î»k=0.0subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜0.0\lambda_{k}=0.0 and the optimal hcsubscriptâ„ğ‘h_{c} is given by, hc=ğ’Ÿoddsubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ’Ÿoddh_{c}={\mathscr{D}}_{\text{odd}}. If we learn the models separately, observe that, for each client h^l,ksubscript^â„ğ‘™ğ‘˜\widehat{h}_{l,k} be the empirical estimate and h^csubscript^â„ğ‘\widehat{h}_{c} would be 0.5â‹…ğ’Ÿeven+0.5â‹…ğ’Ÿoddâ‹…0.5subscriptğ’Ÿevenâ‹…0.5subscriptğ’Ÿodd0.5\cdot{\mathscr{D}}_{\text{even}}+0.5\cdot{\mathscr{D}}_{\text{odd}}. Thus, for any Î»Â¯Â¯ğœ†\bar{\lambda}, the algorithm would incur at least a constant loss more than optimal for any Î»ksubscriptğœ†ğ‘˜\lambda_{k} for odd clients.

Since training models independently is sub-optimal in certain cases, we propose a joint-optimization algorithm. First observe that the optimization can be rewritten as

minhcâ€‹âˆ‘k=1pmkmâ€‹minhÂ¯lâ€‹Î»Â¯â¡â„’ğ’Ÿ^kâ€‹((1âˆ’Î»k)â€‹hc+Î»kâ€‹hl,k).subscriptsubscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptsuperscriptğ‘ğ‘˜1subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜ğ‘šsubscriptsubscriptÂ¯â„ğ‘™Â¯ğœ†subscriptâ„’subscript^ğ’Ÿğ‘˜1subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğœ†ğ‘˜subscriptâ„ğ‘™ğ‘˜\min_{h_{c}}\sum^{p}_{k=1}\frac{m_{k}}{m}\min_{\bar{h}_{l}\bar{\lambda}}{\mathscr{L}}_{\widehat{{\mathscr{D}}}_{k}}((1-\lambda_{k})h_{c}+\lambda_{k}h_{l,k}).

Notice that for a fixed Î»ğœ†\lambda the function is convex in both hâ„“superscriptâ„â„“h^{\ell} and hcsubscriptâ„ğ‘h_{c}. But with the minimization over Î»ğœ†\lambda, the function is no longer convex. We propose algorithm Mapper for minimizing the interpolation models. At each round, the algorithm randomly selects a client. It then finds the best local model and interpolation weight for that client using the current value of the global model. It then updates the global model using the local model and the interpolation weight found in the previous step.

F.1 Synthetic dataset

Let Uğ‘ˆU be a uniform distribution over ğ’´ğ’´{\mathscr{Y}}. Let Pksubscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜P_{k} be a point mass distribution with Pkâ€‹(k)=1.0subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘˜1.0P_{k}(k)=1.0 and for all yâ‰ kğ‘¦ğ‘˜y\neq k, Pkâ€‹(y)=0subscriptğ‘ƒğ‘˜ğ‘¦0P_{k}(y)=0. For a client kğ‘˜k, let ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜{\mathscr{D}}_{k} be a mixture given by

ğ’Ÿk=0.5â‹…Pk%â€‹4+0.25â‹…U+0.25â‹…Pk%â€‹(dâˆ’4),subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜â‹…0.5subscriptğ‘ƒpercentğ‘˜4â‹…0.25ğ‘ˆâ‹…0.25subscriptğ‘ƒpercentğ‘˜ğ‘‘4{\mathscr{D}}_{k}=0.5\cdot P_{k\%4}+0.25\cdot U+0.25\cdot P_{k\%(d-4)},

F.2 EMNIST dataset

For the EMNIST experiments, we follow previous work for model architectureÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019). The full model architecture layer by layer is provided in TableÂ 4. We train the model for 1000 communication rounds with 20 clients per round and use server side momentum, though one can use different optimizersÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2019). Evaluating the combined effect of our approach and adaptive optimizers remains an interesting open direction. Additionally, we apply logit smoothing with weight = 0.9 to the loss function to mitigate against exploding gradients experienced often in training federated models.

For all algorithms, the following hyperparameters are the same: client batch size=20, num clients per round=20, num rounds=1000, server learning rate=1.0, server momentum=0.9. For the remaining hyperparameters, we perform a sweep over parameters and use the eval dataset to choose the best. The best hyperparameters after sweeping are as follows.

  • â€¢

    FedAvg: client num epochs=1, client step size=0.05.

  • â€¢

    Agnostic: client num epochs=1, client step size=0.05, domain learning rate=0.05. NIST documentation shows that the EMNIST dataset comes from two writer sources: Census and High SchoolÂ (Grother, 1995). We use these two distinct sources as domains.

  • â€¢

    HypCluster: client num epochs=1, client step size=0.03, num clusters=2. We determined that 2 was the optimal number of clusters since for larger numbers of clusters, all clients essentially mapped to just 2 of them.

  • â€¢

    Finetune: client num epochs=5, client step size=0.01. We use the best baseline model as the pre-trained starting global model and finetune for each client.

  • â€¢

    Dapper: client num epochs=1, client step size=0.04. Similar to Finetune, we use the best baseline model as the pre-trained starting global model. For each client, we finetune the global model using a mixture of global and client data. Given mksubscriptğ‘šğ‘˜m_{k} client examples, we sample 5â‹…mkâ‹…5subscriptğ‘šğ‘˜5\cdot m_{k} global examples.

  • â€¢

    Mapper: client num epochs=1, client step size=0.03 . We use the same global hyperparameters as the starting global model with the above local hyperparameters. As stated previously, we use the same architecture for both local and global models and at each optimization step, we initialize the local model using the global parameters.

Over the course of running experiments, we observed a peculiar behavior regarding the original client ordering provided in the EMNIST dataset. If the seen and unseen split is performed on the original ordering of clients, the model performance between seen and unseen clients is very different. In particular, unseen is almost 10%percent1010\% absolute worse than seen. Looking through the NIST documentation, we found that the data was sourced from two distinct sources: Census and High SchoolÂ (Grother, 1995). The original client ordering is derived from the data partition they are sourced from and High School clients were all in one split, resulting in the difference in model performance. Thus, we determined that shuffling the clients before splitting was better.
